newsitem.title: USA: Ohio ballot won't include school funding reform.
newsitem.headline: Ohio ballot won't include school funding reform.

text.p: Ohio lawmakers have failed to reach accord on financing school funding reforms and will not place referendums for the overhaul before voters in November, a legislative spokeswoman said Monday.

Ohio lawmakers reached an impasse late Sunday when the House approved a modified funding plan almost immediately rejected by the Senate, said Cheryl Burchard, spokeswoman for House Speaker Jo Ann Davidson, R-Reynoldsburg.
Legislative leaders and Gov. George Voinovich may meet again next week to map out a new school funding plan, Burchard said.
Ohio Supreme Court justices in March found that the state's education funding method relied too heavily on local property taxes and gave lawmakers one year to adopt a new method.

A Voinovich task force recommended raising the state sales tax to generate $1.1 billion of annual revenues to reduce dependence on property taxes. The task force also recommended $5.8 billion of bonds for school construction over 10 years.
Ohio Senate approved the sales tax increase last week, but the state House backed an alternative plan Sunday that was rejected by senators.

The Senate plan also included a property tax increase on businesses and a property tax cut for individuals that would have made the net school funding increase less than the task force recommendations.
The House proposal earmarked a percentage of the general revenue fund for education and pledged $300 million of bonds per year over 10 years for capital improvements.

Lawmakers approved plans requiring school districts to create "rainy day" funds and budget forecasts last week by simple majority votes. The proposed tax increases required 60 percent approval for placement on the ballot.
